description:
android: Improve ActivityStatus and add ChromiumActivity.

The ActivityStatus class used to track activity state changes is too basic
for some usage scenarios.

This patch does the following:

- Augment ActivityStatus with a new StateListener type that can be
  registered to listen to all activity state changes.

  Also add getActivity(), getState(), registerStateListener()
  and unregisterStateListener() as static method.

- Add a new ChromiumActivity class that all Chromium main activities
  should sub-class, to ensure that the ActivityStatus state is updated
  appropriately.

- Modify all main activities in the Chromium code base to extend
  from ChromiumActivity instead of Activity.

BUG=none


Committed: https://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome?view=rev&revision=171789

messages.text:
https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java
File base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode76
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:76: public void onActivityStatusChanged(boolean isPaused);
Note that I'm pretty sure that the Android convention is to avoid the past tense here, i.e. this should be called "onActivityStatusChange" instead. However, I didn't want to update this here for backwards compatibility.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/content/public/android/java/src/org/chromium/content/browser/LocationProvider.java
File content/public/android/java/src/org/chromium/content/browser/LocationProvider.java (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/content/public/android/java/src/org/chromium/content/browser/LocationProvider.java#newcode53
content/public/android/java/src/org/chromium/content/browser/LocationProvider.java:53: if (state == ActivityStatus.PAUSED) {
I suspect this should really be STOPPED / STARTED instead. The PAUSED state means the activity is still visible, e.g. there is a dialog on top of it.

The feature I'm working on (SSL client certificate support) does exactly this, i.e. it prompts the user through a system UI dialog to select a certificate. This will definitely put the activity in the paused state. However, I don't see why we should stop the LocationListener in this case.

The STOPPED state corresponds to the case where the activity is not visible anymore (and even there, do we want to stop the listener if, say, we display the settings activity instead of the main one).

I didn't want to address this in this patch, but I'm curious about your opinions on this topic.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/net/android/java/src/org/chromium/net/NetworkChangeNotifierAutoDetect.java
File net/android/java/src/org/chromium/net/NetworkChangeNotifierAutoDetect.java (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/net/android/java/src/org/chromium/net/NetworkChangeNotifierAutoDetect.java#newcode76
net/android/java/src/org/chromium/net/NetworkChangeNotifierAutoDetect.java:76: if (ActivityStatus.getState() != ActivityStatus.PAUSED) {
Same remark here, do we really want to stop this on pause?

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java
File base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode36
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:36: // List of deprecated pause/resume listeners.
Ignore the "deprecated" here, I'll remove it.

Thanks David and sorry for the nits :)

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java
File base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode18
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:18: // StateListener.onStateChange
Nit: I think this can fit on the line above. Generally we tend to put as much content as possible on lines (100 char limit in Java). I don't know if your editor can do this automatically.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode37
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:37: private ArrayList<Listener> mListeners = new ArrayList<Listener>();
Nit: you can make this field and the one below 'final'.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode49
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:49: sActivity = activity;
Nit: 4 space indentation here and in some other places (e.g. line 55).

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode71
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:71: public interface Listener {
Nit: Maybe add a comment here to say that this listener is kept for backwards compatibility or even that it is deprecated if clients can later switch to the StateListener change interface. Note that there is a @Deprecated annotation in case this can be considered as deprecated.

This would help the reader understand why there are two similar listener interfaces.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode83
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:83: * @param activity Current activity.
Nit: It seems that you got rid of |activity| and |oldState| after you wrote this comment.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode94
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:94: sInstance = new ActivityStatus();
Nit: as a bonus you could add a protected constructor so that clients don't instantiate ActivityStatus without subclassing it if this class is not meant to be used directly (needs to be confirmed though).

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode123
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:123: static public Activity getActivity() {
Nit: I think 'public static' is more common.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/content/public/android/java/src/org/chromium/content/browser/LocationProvider.java
File content/public/android/java/src/org/chromium/content/browser/LocationProvider.java (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1/content/public/android/java/src/org/chromium/content/browser/LocationProvider.java#newcode53
content/public/android/java/src/org/chromium/content/browser/LocationProvider.java:53: if (state == ActivityStatus.PAUSED) {
On 2012/12/04 15:41:55, digit1 wrote:
> I suspect this should really be STOPPED / STARTED instead. The PAUSED state
> means the activity is still visible, e.g. there is a dialog on top of it.
> 
> The feature I'm working on (SSL client certificate support) does exactly this,
> i.e. it prompts the user through a system UI dialog to select a certificate.
> This will definitely put the activity in the paused state. However, I don't see
> why we should stop the LocationListener in this case.
> 
> The STOPPED state corresponds to the case where the activity is not visible
> anymore (and even there, do we want to stop the listener if, say, we display the
> settings activity instead of the main one).
> 
> I didn't want to address this in this patch, but I'm curious about your opinions
> on this topic.

This seems too aggressive indeed. Let's see what the others think.

thanks for the comments, I've addressed them in the latest patch

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1014/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java
File base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1014/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode53
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:53: sActivity = activity;
Nit: I don't know what the general consensus is about single statement if/for/while statements and the use of braces in Chromium Java code.

Personally I prefer omitting the braces as you did. The only thing is that this file is now using the two ways of doing.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1014/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode74
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:74: // This interface can only be used to listen to PAUSED and RESUMED
Nit: I think that Javadoc comments are preferred at the class/interface/method level. I'm not sure this is true in Chromium though. The other reviewers can clarify this.

LG for the files I commented on. (didn't read it all)

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1014/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java
File base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1014/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode53
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:53: sActivity = activity;
On 2012/12/04 17:49:21, Philippe wrote:
> Nit: I don't know what the general consensus is about single statement
> if/for/while statements and the use of braces in Chromium Java code.
> 
> Personally I prefer omitting the braces as you did. The only thing is that this
> file is now using the two ways of doing.

In java (contrary to c++), an if() statement must either be 1 line, or 3 or more. i.e. here it must either be all be on one line, or use braces.

This is following android java conventions (AIUI)

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/11419287/diff/1014/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java#newcode74
base/android/java/src/org/chromium/base/ActivityStatus.java:74: // This interface can only be used to listen to PAUSED and RESUMED
On 2012/12/04 17:49:21, Philippe wrote:
> Nit: I think that Javadoc comments are preferred at the class/interface/method
> level. I'm not sure this is true in Chromium though. The other reviewers can
> clarify this.

yes,
Java DOC if it's something the caller needs to know, // comment for an implementation note that's more of interest to the future maintainer of the method itself

as this is deprecated, kind of moot.

lgtm

This sounds reasonable to me, too.
